Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Evaluation of new nanomaterials as sensing agents using a charge-based separation technique
Award.AbstractNarration:
The recent discovery of nanomaterials - chemical materials smaller than bacteria - has sparked new research on their varied properties and potential applications. This study will compare the utility of two nanomaterials - gold nanoparticles and graphene quantum dots- as sensing agents for proteins. Improved detection of proteins implicated in a variety of human health issues is increasingly important as new threats to wellness emerge. New methods employing these nanomaterials, in conjunction with a high resolution separation technique, will be developed to provide the selective and sensitive detection of target molecules. Currently, nanomaterials used for biomolecular labeling include inorganic quantum dots and gold nanoparticles, which can be toxic or too expensive for routine use. The goals of this research are to develop and better understand the properties and applications of safer and more economical nanomaterial alternatives as probes for molecular sensing. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Saito, a noted expert in applied separations, at Saitama University in Japan.

Graphene-based quantum dots are new nanomaterials with the potential to circumvent the toxicity and expense of currently utilized nanomaterials. These nanomaterials, when used as chemical modifiers in capillary electrophoresis, or CE, promise to provide faster and easier detection of proteins like calmodulin (CaM) - a small, ubiquitous calcium-sensing protein that is diagnostic of calcium related diseases. The sensing capabilities of the nanomaterials will be evaluated by CE methods, which will rely on enhanced detection sensitivity afforded by changes in the fluorescence response of the nanomaterials upon interaction with the free and calcium-bound forms of the CaM. These nanomaterials are expected to serve as sensitive molecular probes for enhanced detection, and as effective separation modifiers, improving the resolution of bioanalytes in complex mixtures. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The nature of the project was to utilize spectrofluorometry and capillary electrophoresis (CE), a separation technique based on the charge and size of the analytes in an applied electric field, to increase our understanding of the properties and potential applications of new, in-house synthesized graphene quantum dots (GQDs) as luminescent probes and auxiliary agents for calmodulin protein (CaM) and transferrin protein (Tf) determinations, and to compare the utility of these GQDs to to commercial gold nanoparticles (Au-NPs) and commercial GQDs. Nanomaterials are increasingly used for a variety of applications, especially imaging and molecular sensing. Specifically, GQDs are preferable because they exhibit similar physical and chemical properties as gold nanoparticles (Au-NPs), making them potential fluorescent probes with the added advantages of biocompatibility, low cytotoxicity and low cost. Thus, GQDs warrant a thorough exploration of preparation and separation techniques as well as an examination of their optical properties. Utilizing GQDs for enhanced biomolecular detection and separation via modified CE methods promises to provide faster, more selective and sensitive determinations of proteins like Tf and CaM. This research has the potential to impact the fields of chemistry, physics, materials science, medical science, nanoscience, and human resources, which includes continued collaboration with the Saito lab at Saitama University, where the NSF-EAPSI fellow (L. Sirkisoon) started this project.

 

Work conducted at Saitama University involved testing Au-NPs, in-house synthesized GQDs and commercial GQDs with apo- (no Fe3+ bound) and holo-(two Fe3+ bound) Tf, as well as testing Au-NPs and GQDs with apo- (no Ca2+ bound) and holo- (four Ca2+ bound) CaM, for enhancement of the inherent fluorescence of the nanomaterial. Fluorescence enhancement of the in-house synthesized GQDs was observed with apo- and holo-Tf and with apo- and holo-CaM, whereas inconsistent results were obtained for the commercial GQDs with apo- and holo-Tf, possibly due to degradation of the commercially sourced nanomaterial sample. The Au-NPs were not inherently fluorescent under the conditions employed; therefore, only CE studies UV/Vis absorbance detection were completed with this type of nanomaterial.

 

The significant results from this work are the successful separation of apo- and holo-Tf using the in-house synthesized GQDs as auxiliary agents in the separation buffer. Furthermore, an additional peak was resolved in the electropherograms obtained with GQD-modified buffers for the sample containing a mixture of apo-and holo-Tf protein standards. This new peak is believed to correspond to the single iron bound state of Tf. These results suggest that GQDs can be used as auxiliary agents to separate metalloproteins by interacting differently with the different conformations of metalloproteins. The studies involving Au-NPs as auxiliary agents showed no separation enhancement for mixtures of apo- and holo-forms of Tf and CaM.  Whereas the GQDs did not lead to separation enhancement for mixtures of apo- and holo-CaM, the GQDs did, however, show differences in fluorescence enhancement by luminescence spectroscopy for apo- and holo-CaM, thus suggesting promise for CE-LIF studies. Future studies will involve a thorough exploration of the interaction of GQDs with apo- and holo-Tf and other metalloproteins by analyzing the effects of incubation time, pH, composition of the separation buffer, GQD concentration, and GQD modifications.

 

The intellectual merit of this project is an increased understanding of the properties of GQDs based on spectrofluorometric and CE-UV/Vis analyses of GQDs with Tf and CaM. The spectrofluorometric studies indicate that GQDs interact with apo- and holo- Tf and apo- an...

These results suggest that GQDs can be used as auxiliary agents to separate metalloproteins by interacting differently with the different conformations of metalloproteins. The studies involving Au-NPs as auxiliary agents showed no separation enhancement for mixtures of apo- and holo-forms of Tf and CaM. The intellectual merit of this project is an increased understanding of the properties of GQDs based on spectrofluorometric and CE-UV/Vis analyses of GQDs with Tf and CaM. The spectrofluorometric studies indicate that GQDs interact with apo- and holo- Tf and apo- and holo-CaM in a manner dependent upon protein conformation.
